Nike can move to the PORT CY vs inland, depending on your target TEU for

Under Clause 14.6 of the Nike Global Ocean Freight Agreement (which we were

referring to as a master service agreement or MSA), Nike has the sole

discretion to determine if cargo is a total loss or if it can be salvaged.

If Nike determines it is a total loss, then ONE is liable for the value of

the goods in accordance with the Claims Template.

Under the service contract with Nike, we agreed to an "average" gross

profit ratio for cargo claims. This markup is based on Nike's (previous

year) revenue vs. cost of goods sold. For example against the current

contract, the gross profit ratio based on Nike's FY24 in the claims

template is 180.3758%.

As an example, if Nike provides us with a commercial invoice of $100, we

agreed that the market price for that same claim would be $180.73 and we

would pay them $180.73 (based on the gross profit ratio). Nike would not

have to provide market price documents to show the $180.73.

Best Regards,

Dears good day

Please note that we need the police report to validate all the information

Please note that delays are not terminated until the empty container is

returned or payment of the DV is made.

I'll share with you the procedure in these cases.

\- The customer will have 15 days for the container to appear from the date

of the report. If the container is recovered during this time, delays are

terminated based on the date of the EIR with which the equipment is

returned.

\- If the container does not appear, they have an additional 15 days to pay

the depreciated value and can request support to consider the date of the

theft and/or deduct the delays incurred.

\- If the depreciated value is not paid, the demurrage rate is cut off from

the date the empty container is received, and any delays must be settled

promptly.

Additional Information: The depreciated value and certified cost of the

container must be requested directly from ONE's corporate office in Asia.

The cost of the depreciated value plus a USD 300 administrative fee for

decommissioning the equipment from the fleet must be covered.

Note 1: The depreciated value of the equipment fluctuates depending on the

year of manufacture, type, and size.

Note 2: If the equipment is recovered within the 15 days granted by ONE and

has been delayed by the date indicated in the EIR, the customer must

request a waiver or discount on the amount incurred due to delays with the

ONE office at the origin.
